results.justification: The document explicitly states the research focus on team formation and its challenges. It outlines the approach of designing and evaluating algorithms for this purpose.

Section 4 details the evaluation framework, including scenarios, algorithms, and metrics, providing a step-by-step description of the experimental design. Algorithm 1 provides a pseudocode description of the priority algorithm.

The document mentions using real class data from 2022 and 2023, but does not make it publicly available. It states that students without survey responses were omitted, implying privacy concerns. A link to a repository is provided for algorithms, but not the datasets themselves.
The document describes the characteristics and distributions of the student data used in the real class scenarios (Section 4.2), providing a form of data documentation.
The document states that data was collected from a survey (Section 4.2), describing the type of information gathered (e.g., background information, timeslot availabilities).
The document states: "The Algorithms repository is available at https://github.com/Teamable-Analytics/algorithms."
While the document mentions data preprocessing, it does not explicitly state whether the code for data cleaning and preparation is shared in the repository.

The document presents quantitative results (e.g., runtime comparisons, performance metrics) and discusses statistical comparisons between algorithms. Metrics like intra-heterogeneity and solo status are used for quantitative evaluation.
The document primarily focuses on quantitative analysis and does not include significant qualitative data or interpretation.
The document does not mention or link to any preregistration.
The document presents detailed results from both synthetic and real-world data experiments, including tables and figures comparing the performance of different algorithms.
Section 6.1 discusses limitations, including the need for more comparison algorithms and testing on more student distributions. Section 5.1 also acknowledges potential biases.
